newsitem.title: DUBAI: Saudi starts paying back farmers $800 mln arrears.
newsitem.headline: Saudi starts paying back farmers $800 mln arrears.

text.p: Saudi Arabia started paying more than three billion riyals ($800 million) to holders of special farmers certificates on maturity on Saturday, bankers said.
"SAMA (Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency or central bank) is crediting us automatically with the value of our holdings," said one Riyadh-based banker.
"SAMA is issuing payment orders to some banks on behalf of farmers," said another.

The special payment certificates which matured on Saturday, are the first of three tranches of a more than nine billion riyal issue made earlier this year to meet government arrears up to end-1995 to some 30,000 farmers in the kingdom.
Faced with huge Gulf War liabilities and soft oil prices, Saudi Arabia fell behind on payments to farmers in the past few years, causing painful cash crunches.

Banks in the kingdom have held some of the certificates since buying them off cash-strapped farmers at a discount ahead of the official redemption date after SAMA in March gave banks the go-ahead to do so.
While many of the payments by SAMA, on behalf of the Finance Ministry, are made electronically, some farmers can collect their money from SAMA branches around their kingdom.
"Today, the first day will be very crowded, so we will wait a few days," said one farmer of the SAMA branch where he expected to redeem his certificates.
The outstanding certificates, worth more than six billion riyals, mature in August 1997 and August 1998.
